author: By Jenny Marder
title: A Full-Body Strength Training Workout at Home
description: If you’re willing to be creative, a set of elastic bands can be as effective as a gym full of weights.
content: Not long ago, I impulsively bought a set of mini exercise bands — thick rubber loops designed to engage your muscles as you stretch them. I was seduced by ads promising they could improve my posture, which is lousy after years of slumping over a computer. They claimed a handful of quick exercises would unhunch my shoulders while I “tone my muscles” and “sculpt my physique.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Erlanger and Anton Troianovski
title: Far From Defeated, Putin Intends to Escalate War in Ukraine
description: Austria’s chancellor said after meeting with Mr. Putin that the Russian president had “totally adopted the logic of war.”
content: Austria’s chancellor visited President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia on Monday — the first Western leader to see him in person since the Ukraine invasion — and said he came away feeling not only pessimistic about peace prospects but fearing that Mr. Putin intended to drastically intensify the brutality of the war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Draper
title: ‘This Was Trump Pulling a Putin’
description: Amid the current crisis, Fiona Hill and other former advisers are connecting President Trump’s pressure campaign on Ukraine to Jan. 6. And they’re ready to talk.
content: Fiona Hill vividly recalls the first time she stepped into the Oval Office to discuss the thorny subject of Ukraine with the president. It was February of 2008, the last year of George W. Bush’s administration. Hill, then the national intelligence officer for Russia and Eurasia for the National Intelligence Council, was summoned for a strategy session on the upcoming NATO summit in Bucharest, Romania. Among the matters up for discussion was the possibility of Ukraine and another former Soviet state, Georgia, beginning the process of obtaining NATO membership.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs, Michael D. Shear and Eileen Sullivan
title: A pandemic rule is among the Trump-era immigration policies that has divided the White House.
description: WASHINGTON — President Biden came into office promising to dismantle what he described as the inhumane immigration policies of President Donald J. Trump. But for much of Mr. Biden’s presidency so far, the White House has been divided by furious debates over how — and whether — to proceed in the face of a surge of migrants crossing the southwest border. And the internal battles have not been limited to the immigration agencies.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden came into office promising to dismantle what he described as the inhumane immigration policies of President Donald J. Trump. But for much of Mr. Biden’s presidency so far, the White House has been divided by furious debates over how — and whether — to proceed in the face of a surge of migrants crossing the southwest border. And the internal battles have not been limited to the immigration agencies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giulia Heyward
title: Virus outbreaks are pushing some U.S. universities to reinstate mask mandates.
description: A handful of U.S. colleges and universities are reverting to the past pandemic protocol because of rising cases on campuses.
content: A small number of U.S. colleges and universities are reinstating mask policies, citing coronavirus outbreaks on campus. Their regulation changes come as a highly transmissible Omicron subvariant, known as BA.2, has become the dominant version among new U.S. cases, which are ticking up.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Penn
title: PG&E agrees to pay $55 million in penalties and costs over two wildfires.
description: The California utility settled civil charges and avoided criminal prosecution over the role of its equipment in igniting the blazes.
content: Pacific Gas & Electric agreed on Monday to pay $55 million in penalties and costs to settle civil cases brought by prosecutors over wildfires across six Northern California counties.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penn Bullock and Daniel E. Slotnik
title: Your Monday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Vivian Giang, Stephen Gandel, Lauren Hirsch, Ephrat Livni, Anna Schaverien and David F. Gallagher
title: Elon Musk Backs Out
description: The world’s wealthiest man decided not to join Twitter’s board after all.
content: A week ago, we learned that Elon Musk had purchased a big stake in Twitter. Shortly after, the billionaire chief of Tesla — and Twitter power user — was invited to join the social media company’s board.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: What Happened When 150,000 Songbirds Descended Into Music City
description: A vast flock of purple martins has made Nashville’s symphony center its staging ground for the fall migration. It’s not just the city’s problem. It’s a human problem.
content: NASHVILLE — In the summer of 2020, a massive flock of purple martins set up camp in the trees surrounding the Schermerhorn Symphony Center, in the heart of downtown Nashville. The birds had left their nesting territories, both nearby and farther north, and were gathering in preparation for the fall migration. They stayed for two months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
title: Is Trump the Democrats’ Secret Weapon?
description: There are days when it certainly seems that way.
content: Bret Stephens: Hi, Gail. I was moved by Ketanji Brown Jackson’s remarks last week after her Senate confirmation: “In my family, it took just one generation to go from segregation to the Supreme Court.” What a ringing affirmation of what’s possible in the United States. And how depressing that only three Republican senators could bring themselves to vote for her, if only on the principle that every president deserves to get qualified nominees confirmed. Whatever happened to acknowledging the possibility that we can respect and admire people with whom we also disagree?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carole Landry
title: Russia’s Buildup in the East
description: Satellite images show a column of Russian military vehicles moving toward the new front.
content: Good evening. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage
title: U.S. Weighs Shift to Support Hague Court as It Investigates Russian Atrocities
description: The government is hamstrung from helping the world’s war-crimes court by two laws and a policy aimed at barring it from charging Americans.
content: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration is vigorously debating how much the United States can or should assist an investigation into Russian atrocities in Ukraine by the International Criminal Court in The Hague, according to officials familiar with internal deliberations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: Arbitrator Clears Buffalo Police Officers Who Shoved Protester
description: A video from June 2020 showed Martin Gugino, 75 at the time, motionless and bleeding after being pushed to the ground. The footage fueled outrage during a summer of unrest over police violence.
content: Two Buffalo police officers who shoved a 75-year-old man to the ground during a protest in 2020 have been cleared by an arbitrator, who said the use of force was “absolutely legitimate” because the man, who was hospitalized with a head injury, was “not an innocent bystander.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: dismal
description: This word has appeared in 162 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word dismal has appeared in 162 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on March 25 in “Why Californians Have Been Saving Less Water in 2022” by Soumya Karlamangla:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Rubinstein and Nicole Hong
title: As Remote Work Becomes Permanent, Can Manhattan Adapt?
description: With more companies adopting hybrid work, New York City’s economy, which relies on commuters and full office buildings, faces an uncertain future.
content: PwC, a global consulting firm with its American headquarters in New York City, has told 40,000 of its United States employees that they can work remotely forever. Quinn Emanuel Urquhart & Sullivan, a white-shoe law firm with about 300 lawyers in New York, is allowing its staff to live anywhere in the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: MONDAY — Administrative note: Thank you for your patience! Please refresh your web pages and reopen your applications. You should see a new Spelling Bee puzzle for today. Happy solving!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roni Caryn Rabin
title: New Drug Slashed Deaths Among Patients With Severe Covid, Maker Claims
description: A late-stage trial was halted after strong early results, according to the company, but the data have not yet been published or peer-reviewed.
content: An experimental drug halved the death rate among critically ill Covid patients who were receiving supplemental oxygen and were at high risk for serious lung disease and death, the drug’s developer announced on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracey Tully
title: Legal Marijuana Sales Expected to Start Within Weeks in New Jersey
description: A state commission has granted seven medical-marijuana companies permission to start selling cannabis to all adults at 13 dispensaries.
content: A year and a half after New Jersey residents voted to legalize cannabis, the state on Monday gave seven medical-marijuana companies approval to start selling their products to all adults, opening the door to the first legal marijuana sales in the New York City region within a month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Beggs
title: The Bust Economy Is Booming
description: Interest in busts has grown as the art form, once accessible to a wealthy few, has become more democratic than ever.
content: Meet Glenda. She has wisps of gold in her white hair, melatonin-drooped eyes and a tragic lack of torso.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: ‘Cheap as Chips’ No Longer True in U.K. as Prices Soar for a Favorite Meal
description: The costs for fish and chips, a working-class staple in Britain for well over a century, have rocketed as the war in Ukraine has made the main ingredients scarcer. Of 10,000 shops, 3,000 may close.
content: HARTLEPOOL, England — When it opened in 2020, business was booming at Chunks, a store serving dozens of portions each day of Britain’s best known takeout meal: battered and deep-fried cod with fries, or chips as they are known here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘Sway'
title: Paul Krugman on Why the Economy Is Doing Better Than We Think
description: The economist and Times Opinion columnist discusses inflation, unemployment and the supply chain crisis.
content: From rising gas prices and inflation to the Russia-Ukraine war, the U.S. economy has experienced all sorts of turbulence recently. But it hasn’t all been a bad news story: The U.S. unemployment rate reached a low of 3.6 percent in March and wages are rising. In this conversation, Kara Swisher asks the economist and Nobel laureate Paul Krugman to put all these factors into perspective. “It’s not an A++ economy,” Krugman says, but it’s “immensely better” than where the economy was during the 2008 financial crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Nolen and Finbarr O'Reilly
title: This Psychiatric Hospital Used to Chain Patients. Now It Treats Them.
description: Sierra Leone, one of the world’s poorest countries, is working to build a modern mental health system from scratch.
content: FREETOWN, Sierra Leone — For centuries, they called the foreboding building on a hill above this capital city the Kissy Lunatic Asylum. It was built in the early 1800s by the British colonial administration, and behind the high walls, patients were kept in chains. People here say the stench seeped from the brick walls, and the screams of patients, whose psychosis and trauma were untreated by medication or therapy, echoed out the narrow, barred windows.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Newberger Goldstein
title: Liana Finck Imagines a Female God, in Her Own Image
description: The cartoonist’s new graphic novel, “Let There Be Light,” recasts the story of Genesis with God as a neurotic artist a lot like Liana Finck.
content: Here’s a short and sweet (and fallacious) argument for God’s existence. 1: Our idea of God is of a supremely perfect being — meaning a being that has all perfections, such as omniscience, omnipotence and beneficence. 2: Necessary existence is a perfection. Conclusion: God exists.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Your Tuesday Briefing: Documenting Russia’s Terror Campaign
description: Plus, Japan takes a step away from its pacifist identity and South Korea eases restrictions.
content: A mother killed by a sniper while walking with her family to fetch a thermos of tea. A woman held as a sex slave, naked except for a fur coat and locked in a potato cellar before being executed. Two sisters dead in their home, their bodies left slumped on the floor for weeks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick McGeehan
title: ‘S.N.L.’ Star Colin Jost Takes a Spin on Ferryboat He Bought With Pete Davidson
description: After buying the retired Staten Island ferry at auction in January, the new owners rode it into New York Harbor en route to a temporary home.
content: Colin Jost, one of the stars of “Saturday Night Live,” has ridden the Staten Island Ferry across New York Harbor many times. But Monday he rode one for the first time as its owner.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Campbell Robertson
title: The city of Philadelphia will reinstate an indoor mask mandate, the first major U.S. city to do so this spring.
description: The move comes a little more than a month after the city lifted it.
content: With new coronavirus cases low but rising sharply in recent days, the city of Philadelphia announced on Monday that it will reinstate an indoor mask mandate a little more than a month after lifting it, becoming the first major U.S. city to do so.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: Ukraine Benefit Featuring Russian Ensemble Is Canceled in Vienna
description: Organizers said they canceled a performance by MusicAeterna after the Ukrainian ambassador in Austria expressed concern about featuring Russian artists.
content: A planned benefit concert in support of Ukraine was canceled in Vienna on Monday amid concerns about the Russian-based ensemble it was to feature, MusicAeterna, which is led by the conductor Teodor Currentzis and is supported by a state-owned bank in Russia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danielle Braff
title: Saying Goodbye to the Plain White Wedding Gown
description: As couples seek to plan nuptials that feel more personal, many are eschewing tradition. But this may be the most visible break yet.
content: Elizabeth Arasevi had no intention to follow custom when it came to choosing a wedding dress.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Skolnick and Hilary Swift
title: A Mentalist Sets a Central Park Running Record (Just as He Foresaw)
description: Oz Pearlman, better known as Oz the Mentalist, ran 19 loops of Central Park — 116 miles — in a single day.
content: Before sunrise last Friday, Oz Pearlman loosened up in front of Engineers’ Gate, one of the entrances to Central Park. He rubbed up his thighs and underarms with petroleum jelly, then peeled off his toe socks and coated his feet. This would not be a typical weekday morning jaunt through Manhattan’s preferred and most storied running terrain.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Trade and Peace: The Great Illusion
description: Sometimes globalization ends up empowering autocracy.
content: On April 12, 1861, rebel artillery opened fire on Fort Sumter, beginning the U.S. Civil War. The war eventually became a catastrophe for the South, which lost more than a fifth of its young men. But why did the secessionists believe they could pull it off?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mujib Mashal
title: With India on the fence over Ukraine, Biden meets with Modi.
description: India, heavily dependent on Russian weapons, has long tried not to take sides between Moscow and Washington. It has refrained from denouncing Russia’s invasion or imposing sanctions.
content: President Biden emphasized growing defense cooperation with India in a virtual meeting with Prime Minister Narendra Modi on Monday — a line U.S. officials have increasingly touted in the hopes of convincing New Delhi to come off the fence over Russia’s war on Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Mozur, Steven Lee Myers and John Liu
title: China’s Echoes of Russia’s Alternate Reality Intensify Around the World
description: China’s officials and state media are increasingly parroting Russian propaganda organs on the war in Ukraine, undercutting U.S. and European diplomatic efforts, even after the killings in Bucha.
content: When Twitter put up a warning message atop a Russian government post denying civilian killings in Bucha, Ukraine, last week, China’s state media rushed to its defense. “On Twitter @mfa_russia’s statement on #Bucha got censored,” wrote Frontline, a Twitter account associated with China’s official English-language broadcaster, CGTN.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Isaac and Kate Conger
title: Twitter Grapples With an Elon Musk Problem
description: Mr. Musk, Twitter’s biggest shareholder, is free to buy more stock in the company and could use the platform against itself. Some employees are dismayed.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — Bright and early on Monday, Elon Musk sent the government a surprising new document.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: W.N.B.A. Draft: Kentucky’s Rhyne Howard Goes No. 1 to Dream
description: Howard, a senior guard, was the top pick after Atlanta made a deal with the Washington Mystics to move up in the draft.
content: The Atlanta Dream, looking for a versatile player to help rebuild their roster, selected guard Rhyne Howard from the University of Kentucky as the No. 1 pick in the W.N.B.A. draft on Monday at Spring Studios in New York.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Cost of Fish and Chips Rises in War Economy, and U.K. Feels the Bite
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, April 11, 2022.
content: “There’s a bit of theater in a fish-and-chip shop, it’s a bit like being behind a bar. I’ve got customers that just come in for the banter and, for some of the older people, we might be the only people they speak to all day.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Diana Nguyen, Mooj Zadie, Clare Toeniskoetter, Kaitlin Roberts, Lisa Tobin, Mike Benoist, John Ketchum, Marion Lozano, Dan Powell and Chris Wood
title: How Two Friends Beat Amazon and Built a Union
description: A conversation with the warehouse workers who created the e-commerce giant’s first union against all odds.
content: This episode contains strong language.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Fabi
title: What It’s Like to Compete at a Crossword Puzzle Tournament
description: A Wordplay columnist’s diary from one of the biggest solving events of the year.
content: Nothing could have prepared me for the 2022 American Crossword Puzzle Tournament — not the 2006 documentary “Wordplay”; not reading up on the history and lore of the event; certainly not my participation in the virtual A.C.P.T., which replaced the in-person event in 2021. From the surreal joy of meeting hundreds of other crossword lovers in real life to the sound of hundreds of solvers flipping their puzzles faceup at the same time, this year’s A.C.P.T. was an amazing experience.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $1.9 Million Homes in California
description: A midcentury-modern home in Rancho Mirage, a two-bedroom condominium in San Francisco and a 1954 ranch house in St. Helena.
content: This house was designed by Richard Leitch, a U.S.C.-trained architect who worked extensively in California’s desert resort cities during the mid-20th century. The home, which has been featured in a number of films and magazines, was renovated by the current owner, who updated it while maintaining its historic character, salvaging original details wherever possible.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Ewing
title: Truck Makers Face a Tech Dilemma: Batteries or Hydrogen?
description: Under pressure to cut emissions, truck manufacturers are choosing between batteries and hydrogen fuel cells. Wagering incorrectly could cost them billions of dollars.
content: Even before war in Ukraine sent fuel prices through the roof, the trucking industry was under intense pressure to kick its addiction to diesel, a major contributor to climate change and urban air pollution. But it still has to figure out which technology will best do the job.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Arraf and Mauricio Lima
title: No More ‘Have a Nice Day’: Lviv Learns to Live With War
description: Ukraine’s cultural capital, the western city of Lviv, is trying to adjust to being on the fringes of war and at the center of massive displacement.
content: LVIV, Ukraine — When war came to Ukraine in February, Helen Polishchuk made some adjustments in the six-story bar she manages in central Lviv.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Proulx
title: What Does Judge Jackson’s Supreme Court Confirmation Mean to You?
description: Judge Ketanji Brown Jackson will be the first Black woman and the first public defender to serve as a justice. How do you think she will shape the court, now and in the future?
content: On April 7, Judge Ketanji Brown Jackson was confirmed to the Supreme Court in a 53-to-47 vote, with three Republicans joining all 50 members of the Democratic caucus in backing her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: 60 Seconds with Rachel Simon
description: A chat with one of the New York Times Crossword constructors.
content: I love how crossword puzzles continually teach me new things — whether it’s an uncommon word, a fun fact, or a little-known piece of history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Books That Make Us Think of Home: A Virtual Times Conversation
description: The writer Saeed Jones will join Times editors to discuss their personal favorites, and they want to hear from you.
content: What are the books that bring to mind a place where you have lived? The books that give you a sense of community, create comfort or make you feel like you belong? The books that make you consider what home actually means?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Daniels
title: Lesson of the Day: ‘A Fast, Frugal Track to a Cook’s Career? Community College.’
description: In this lesson, students will learn why some aspiring chefs are choosing community college-based culinary schools. Then, they will research a career that interests them.
content: Featured Article: “A Fast, Frugal Track to a Cook’s Career? Community College.” by Priya Krishna
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Phillips
title: ‘Birthday Candles’ Review: Another Year, Another Cake, Another Profundity
description: Debra Messing expounds on the preciousness of life in a production that aspires to convey eloquent whimsy, but too often feels methodically sentimental.
content: Repetition can make magic happen: repeat a word or a phrase enough times and it breathes new life, fresh meaning. Or repetition can strip language until all that’s left are empty rhythms and sounds. Words are funny like that.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Red Hot Chili Peppers Top Chart With ‘Unlimited Love’
description: The band reunites with its former guitarist, John Frusciante, and the producer Rick Rubin for its latest album.
content: Everything aligned for Red Hot Chili Peppers’ latest album, “Unlimited Love,” which has opened at No. 1 on the Billboard chart, the band’s second time at the top.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Japan’s Perfect Game Drought Ends With a 19-Strikeout Masterpiece
description: Roki Sasaki, 20, pitched the first perfect game in Nippon Professional Baseball in 28 years. But don’t expect to see him in M.L.B. anytime soon.
content: Roki Sasaki’s perfect game was a long time coming, the first in the Japanese majors since 1994. But the wait turned out to be worth it. Sasaki struck out 19 of the 27 men he faced, completing what would have to be described as one of the greatest games ever pitched.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Calabrian Chile Flakes to Use With Abandon
description: Boonville Barn Collective’s chile has a balanced heat that perks up pizza and pasta.
content: Freshness counts with dried crushed chile flakes: Look for bright red shards with an oily sheen, and more vibrancy on the palate. The new Boonville Barn Collective Calabrian Chile Flakes, from the 2021 fall harvest, deliver an almost floral aroma and balanced, lingering heat with a whisper of sweetness. Use with abandon on pizza, in linguine with clams, even over steamed lobster. The Northern California company was previously called Piment d’Ville, and is known for Espelette chile powder. Krissy Scommegna and Gideon Burdick took over ownership and gave it a new name in 2020, and expanded the inventory with assorted whole dried chiles and chile powders, all from chiles that they grow. I only wish the spices came in metal tins instead of transparent jars.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Bittel
title: The Shakespearean Tall Tale That Shaped How We See Starlings
description: Researchers debunked a long-repeated yarn that the common birds owe their North American beginnings to a 19th-century lover of the Bard. Maybe this ubiquitous bird’s story is ready for a reboot.
content: In 1890, a mustachioed eccentric named Eugene Schieffelin released a few dozen European starlings into New York City. His supposed goal? Introduce all the bird species mentioned in William Shakespeare’s plays to America.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Tell Us Your Antiviral Story
description: We may feature your response in the Coronavirus Briefing newsletter.
content: Antiviral medications to treat Covid are becoming more common. Last month, the Biden administration announced its “test to treat” initiative, aimed at providing patients with the medications as soon as they learn they are infected.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sean T. Collins
title: ‘Billions’ Season 6 Finale Recap: Rhoades to Perdition
description: Two men sit in a prosecutor’s office. One will go to jail. Things are about to get complicated.
content: There are times, and this is one of them, when “Billions” feels less like a show to recap than like a show to be decoded. Not because it’s a “Lost”-style mystery-box series, constantly introducing new known unknowns to be theorized about, but because its plotting is so dense and meticulous that if you miss a beat, you miss the point.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Carmel
title: Janelle James Loves Being a Bad Boss in ‘Abbott Elementary’
description: The comedian talks about her breakout acting role as a hilariously terrible elementary school principal in the hit ABC sitcom.
content: Janelle James had no desire to be a TV actress. For years, she was content building a career in stand-up, landing the occasional writing gig or minor onscreen role.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: An exodus from eastern Ukraine.
content: Russian forces attacked civilian areas in eastern Ukraine yesterday as terrified residents fleeing westward joined an exodus of thousands, heeding warnings by the authorities that Russian troops were preparing a major assault. Follow the latest updates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: A Wooden Knife Sharper Than Steel? Scientists Say So.
description: Knives are humanity’s oldest tool, dating back millions of years. A group of scientists in Maryland have produced a version made of hardened wood, which they say is sharper than steel.
content: More than 60 years ago in “Mastering the Art of French Cooking,” Julia Child, one of America’s most emulated chefs, described the necessity of decent, reliable kitchen equipment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Oscar Lopez and Natalie Kitroeff
title: Despite Low Turnout, Mexico Voters Back President to Stay in Office
description: President Andrés Manuel López Obrador drew overwhelming support among those who cast ballots, but the recall referendum failed to achieve the required 40 percent threshold to be binding.
content: MEXICO CITY — Pitched by the president as a landmark exercise for Mexico’s democracy, Sunday’s recall referendum gave voters the chance to remove their head of state from office for the first time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: Benedict Lombe Wins the Blackburn Prize for ‘Lava’
description: The British Congolese playwright earned the $25,000 prize for her memoir-monologue that deals with Black identity and displacement.
content: For the first time in the 44-year history of the Susan Smith Blackburn Prize, awarded annually to a female, transgender or nonbinary playwright who writes for the English-language theater, the honor has gone to the writer of a debut play.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Small
title: New York Lets ‘Fearless Girl’ Hold Her Ground, for Now
description: Officials voted to extend the sculpture’s permit but are requiring stakeholders to return in six months with plans for a permanent location.
content: The popular “Fearless Girl” sculpture will continue to stand outside the New York Stock Exchange after city officials voted on Monday to extend the sculpture’s temporary permit for 11 months. This decision comes with the stipulation that the city, the owner of the sculpture and the artist return in six months with a process for deciding the artwork’s ultimate fate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Motoko Rich
title: With Threats All Around, Japan Moves to Shed Its Pacifist Constraints
description: Growing calls for more military spending after Russia’s invasion of Ukraine demonstrate Japan’s recognition that it must bolster its own deterrent power, not just rely on its U.S. alliance.
content: TOKYO — Late in February, just days after the Russian invasion, Ukraine asked Japan to ship an assortment of military equipment, from antitank weapons and ammunition to electronic radar and bulletproof vests.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annabelle Williams
title: Patricia MacLachlan, ‘Sarah, Plain and Tall’ Author, Dies at 84
description: A best-selling children’s book writer, she focused on family life and its difficulties, earning acclaim for her gentle, sparse prose.
content: Patricia MacLachlan, the celebrated author of children’s books, including the best-selling “Sarah, Plain and Tall,” about a young woman who moves to a pioneer homestead to join a widower and his children, died on March 31 at her home in Williamsburg, Mass. She was 84.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chelsia Rose Marcius, Troy Closson and Grace Ashford
title: New York’s Bail Laws Are Changing Again. Here’s How.
description: Governor Kathy Hochul pushed for a rewrite of the 2019 laws governing the criminal justice system.
content: One of the most contentious items in New York’s $220 billion budget deal had little to do with fiscal issues: For the second time, legislators revised laws governing bail for criminal defendants that they had passed just three years ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Zelensky says Ukraine takes ‘as seriously as possible’ an apparent threat of Russian chemical weapon use.
description: A Ukrainian unit in Mariupol claimed Russian forces had used chemical weapons there. Their report could not be independently confirmed.
content: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine in his latest address seized on an apparent Russian threat to use chemical weapons against the remaining defenders of Mariupol, as they prepare for what he called a “new stage of terror against Ukraine.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Britney Spears, Out of Conservatorship, Says ‘I Am Having a Baby’
description: During her successful effort to end her conservatorship, the performer had complained that the team appointed to supervise her had blocked her from having additional children.
content: Months after Britney Spears was released from the conservatorship that she said was restricting her from having a third child, the pop star announced Monday in an Instagram post that she is pregnant.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives
title: These Photographers Chase New Zealand’s Glowing Waves
description: Capturing bioluminescence, a phenomenon in which glowing algae give crashing waves an electric blue glow, requires technical skill and a bit of luck.
content: On hot, moonless nights in New Zealand, they fan out across beaches in search of an elusive, shimmering quarry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: Tove Ditlevsen’s Fiction Is Bleak and Claustrophobic — Mostly in a Good Way
description: In “The Trouble With Happiness” and “The Faces,” the Danish writer who found posthumous English-language fame with “The Copenhagen Trilogy” writes about women who struggle and settle.
content: Tove Ditlevsen’s “The Copenhagen Trilogy” was one of last year’s major books. It’s a set of three slim memoirs — “Childhood,” “Youth” and “Dependency” — originally published in her native Denmark between 1967 and 1971. They’re told simply but are brutal and lonely, lonely, lonely. It’s as if Ditlevsen were probing a series of aching tooth cavities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tressie McMillan Cottom
title: A New Writing Job Brings Change
description: I’ll continue to address how economics shapes the politics that frame our culture — and vice versa.
content: I was a little nervous when I started publishing this newsletter some six months ago. I knew how to write for the public. From essays to tweets to blogs, I have been writing for almost 20 years. I came to this venture with a pretty clear idea of what a newsletter is: a subgenre, somewhere between an essay and a blog. My version of the newsletter has been open-ended and process-oriented. It takes an audience of curious and brave readers to make this kind of newsletter work. I was nervous about finding that kind of audience at The Times, where so many readers come for the final version of things, as opposed to the drafts that help us make sense of things.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan and Shawn Hubler
title: A Conversation With Gov. Gavin Newsom of California
description: He talked with The Times about why he thinks the Golden State needs to push back against a national wave of conservative legislation.
content: When Rick Perry was governor of Texas in 2013, he made headlines for his repeated attempts to woo businesses away from California. Perry, a Republican, showed up in Sacramento and bought radio ads decrying California’s taxes and regulations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ed Shanahan
title: Woman Pleads Guilty to Tackling Black Teen at SoHo Hotel
description: Miya Ponsetto admitted to committing a hate crime in the 2020 episode, parts of which were captured in a widely seen video.
content: A California woman who tackled a Black teenager at a SoHo hotel after falsely accusing him of stealing her cellphone pleaded guilty on Monday to a felony hate crime charge stemming from the altercation. Parts of it were captured in a widely seen video.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Rush
title: I Would Have Never Bought This Home if I Knew It Flooded
description: As the climate changes, flood rules need reform to protect communities on the front lines.
content: I have spent much of the past decade at the soggy edges of this country listening to the people whose homes and businesses flood worse and worse year after year as tides rise higher and storms become stronger. While I still haven’t gotten over the shock of hearing someone describe what it’s like to lose a home or a loved one, another story, submerged in this trauma, has started to surface.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Plant-Based Pastry Dough From Dufour Pastry Kitchens
description: The Bronx company has introduced a vegan option made with flour, water, sea salt and what the company calls “ethically-sourced palm fruit oil.”
content: Dufour Pastry Kitchens, the standard-bearer for frozen butter-based puff pastry dough, now offers a vegan option. The Bronx company, founded in 1985 by Judi Arnold, who died in January at 86, and Carla Krasner, has introduced a plant-based version made with flour, water, sea salt and what the company calls “ethically-sourced palm fruit oil.” It’s easy to handle and bakes up with nice flakiness for preparations like fruit tarts, hors d’oeuvres and mushroom Wellington (trading butter in the recipe for olive oil and omitting any egg wash).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: Globalization Isn’t Over. It’s Changing.
description: Cross-border trade and investment remain surprisingly strong.
content: “Deglobalization” is a word on many people’s lips these days — and understandably so. Russia has been largely cut off from the West for its appalling invasion of Ukraine. The economic marriage of convenience between China and the United States (“Chimerica”) is unraveling. And there’s more and more talk about “re-shoring” — producing more stuff at home — either for national security reasons or to avoid future supply-chain disruptions such as those caused by the Covid-19 pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: An Upper East Side Market Gets Serious About Gluten-Free Foods
description: A new location of Agata & Valentina takes inspiration from stores in Italy and has a gluten-free kitchen.
content: The Valentina half of the Upper East Side fancy food market Agata & Valentina is Agata Musco’s daughter, Valentina Puleo. She is gluten intolerant, with Celiac disease, hence the attention to gluten-free items in a new store opening Thursday across the street from the original. Ms Puleo and Ms. Musco did their homework in Italy, where gluten-free stores are prevalent. At their new store, prepared foods, pastries, breads and pastas are made on the premises in a kitchen totally free of gluten. There will be limited seating, a fresh pizza station, a coffee bar and a grab-and-go section with sandwiches, grain salads and bagels. Groceries, dried pasta, crackers, ice cream, some frozen foods and more will be available. The store will have some packaged kosher-for-Passover, gluten-free items and Easter pastries made in-house.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Philipps
title: Sikhs Sue Marine Corps Over Restrictions on Beards
description: The Marine Corps says it needs uniformity, especially during boot camp, and that beards pose risks. Sikhs say the rules are arbitrary and needlessly burden religious liberty.
content: A Marine artillery captain named Sukhbir Singh Toor has been on a mission over the past year to become the first Sikh in the United States Marine Corps allowed to openly practice his religion while in uniform.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: The Boston Symphony cancels its European tour over virus concerns.
description: The orchestra has also reported a surge in cases among its players.
content: The Boston Symphony Orchestra announced on Monday that it was canceling a four-city tour of Europe because of concerns about the spread of the coronavirus in Europe and the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabe Cohn
title: What’s on TV This Week: ‘The First Lady’ and ‘Abbott Elementary’
description: Viola Davis, Michelle Pfeiffer and Gillian Anderson star in a new series about first ladies in the White House. And “Abbott Elementary” airs its season finale.
content: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, April 11-17. Details and times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Isaac
title: Elon Musk Will Not Join Twitter’s Board, Company Says
description: The announcement reverses a decision last week, when Twitter said Mr. Musk would become a board member after amassing a 9.2 percent stake in the company.
content: Elon Musk, the world’s wealthiest man and the biggest shareholder of Twitter, will no longer join the social media service’s board of directors, the company said late Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Leah Askarinam
title: How a Little-Known Democrat Tries to Hold On
description: Representative Tom O’Halleran of Arizona is seeking re-election as his district leans further toward Trump. His strategy? Don’t change. “I am,” he says, “who I am.”
content: Arizona has a history of producing lightning-rod members of Congress, like Representative Paul Gosar. But the Arizona politician you should be paying attention to — and who can potentially tell us a great deal about Democrats’ hopes of avoiding a 2022 wipeout in the House — probably isn’t on your radar.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tania Ganguli
title: ‘Be Your Own Motivation’: Injured N.B.A. Stars Talk Recovery
description: Paul George is back for the Los Angeles Clippers; Victor Oladipo, for the Miami Heat. The road to return was long but has them back in time for the playoffs.
content: For about a month after he was sidelined with a torn ligament in his right elbow, Paul George could do nothing but wait.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Here’s how much it is costing companies to leave Russia.
description: Companies are announcing the financial hits from pulling business out of Russia.
content: A slew of companies have announced plans to stop business in Russia over the last several weeks, and many of them are now sharing what those decisions may cost them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: ‘What If Africa Was the Birthplace of Fashion?’
description: As the first “amigo” designer for Alber Elbaz’s AZ Factory, Thebe Magugu poses the question — and offers a sneak peek into the collection.
content: Last spring, when the much-loved designer Alber Elbaz unexpectedly died from Covid just after introducing a label called AZ Factory, the fashion world first mourned, then wondered what would happen to his new company, backed by the luxury conglomerate Richemont. How could it go on without him?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jay Caspian Kang
title: Email Is Slow and Creates Distance. That’s Why It’s Great.
description: In defense of a dinosaur.
content: Every morning around 9 o’clock, I walk down a narrow flight of stairs to my basement and fire up my work computer. It is a profoundly stupid machine — a PC with a glass outer case, flashing lights and a graphics card that was state-of-the-art back in 2018. The process of starting my day involves signing into three chat clients — Slack, Telegram and Discord — and clicking through any notification bubbles that might have popped up in the three minutes that have passed since I last checked those same apps on my phone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason DeParle and Tamir Kalifa
title: A One-Woman Rescue Squad for Homeless Students
description: The work of Norma Mercado, a Texas school system’s point person for dealing with homeless young people, is benefiting from a big but temporary surge in federal funding.
content: BASTROP, Texas — By the time she reached school on a recent Monday morning, Norma Mercado had already driven four homeless children to class, one from 30 miles away, having spent the weekend taking a group of homeless students on a college tour and two homeless siblings to buy clothes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: The Trick to Matzo Balls is Bubbles
description: Seltzer keeps them light, but beer, cider or even Champagne can do the trick.
content: Some recipes for matzo balls call for seltzer instead of plain water. It’s an old grandma device to keep them light. So when my granddaughter Julia Fabricant craved matzo balls for the batch of chicken stock she made while quarantining at home from college last winter, she asked for a recipe; mine included seltzer. Though she had matzo meal in the pantry, there was no seltzer in the house. So she improvised and used beer with fine results, but kosher for Passover beer is hard to find. “How about cider?” she suggested. “Or Champagne,” I replied. It works. I’m swapping kosher for Passover sparkling wine for seltzer this year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Monica Simpson
title: To Be Pro-Choice, You Must Have the Privilege of Having Choices
description: We must acknowledge the role that race plays in sexual and reproductive health outcomes in this country.
content: As a queer woman who grew up in North Carolina, I learned at an early age that my Blackness could be a source of great joy — but it could also pose a threat to my safety and autonomy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg and Nancy Wartik
title: A Spring Uptick, or Just Some Notable Positive Cases?
description: Cases are rising and a formal dinner seeded political infections, but public health officials urged calm.
content: Eric Adams, the mayor of New York City, is the latest major political figure to test positive for the coronavirus. Adams is fully vaccinated, has received one booster shot and says he is experiencing very mild symptoms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Red Sox Spoil Yankees’ Plans for an Opening Series Sweep
description: Bobby Dalbec’s home run propelled Boston to victory. The Rays, meanwhile, are baseball’s last unbeaten team.
content: Bobby Dalbec hit a tiebreaking solo homer in the sixth inning and the Boston Red Sox avoided a season-opening sweep against their longtime rival with a 4-3 win over the Yankees on Sunday night.
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: April 11, 2022
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, April 11, 2022.
content: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By German Lopez
title: Russia’s Reset
description: A violent weekend in Ukraine shows how Russia’s goals are shifting.
content: Russia’s attacks on Ukrainian civilians and soldiers in recent days have made clear that its withdrawal from northern Ukraine is more an attempt to reset Vladimir Putin’s invasion than a full retreat. The focus now is on the battle for eastern Ukraine, where Russian forces have deployed brutal tactics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: A Spring Vegetable Matzo Brei From Breads Bakery
description: The store has introduced a new version with spring peas and other vegetables, made in eight-inch rounds like crustless quiches.
content: Matzo brei, a scramble of eggs and broken matzo that’s often a Passover breakfast staple, can be given a loftier assignment at the Seder table. If your observance is not strictly kosher for Passover, you might consider Breads Bakery’s matzo brei to serve alongside the chicken or brisket. They have been making it with mushrooms for several years and now has a version made with spring peas and other vegetables. In eight-inch rounds, like crustless quiches, they serve four to six but are not kosher. Warm them before serving. They are available for pickup at Breads Bakery near Union Square, Lincoln Center and the Upper East Side.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anne Barnard
title: On Day 100, Mayor Adams Has Covid-19
description: Eric Adams tested positive after a series of public events promoting his first 100 days as mayor. He reminded eligible New Yorkers to take antivirals.
content: Good morning. It’s Monday. Today we’ll look at Mayor Eric Adams’s case of Covid-19. He tested positive for the coronavirus just after meeting New Yorkers at several events marking 100 days in office, and is being treated with antiviral medications. And we’ll explain who’s eligible for the medicine and how to get it. It’s easier than you think — we tried it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By D.W. Gibson
title: A Haitian Photojournalist Finds Safety in Manhattan
description: Dieu-Nalio Chéry, who covered the strife that has plagued his country, became a target of the violence himself, but  he and his family received help to settle in New York.
content: Dieu-Nalio Chéry never thought he would leave Haiti, much less that his journey would take him to a high-rise apartment building a block from the Hudson River.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush and Katie Benner
title: Biden Names Former Federal Prosecutor to Lead A.T.F.
description: The president nominated Steven M. Dettelbach to run the troubled agency, seven months after withdrawing his previous pick.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden nominated a former federal prosecutor, Steven M. Dettelbach, on Monday to run the embattled Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives — part of a renewed effort to combat gun violence and jump-start a stalled gun control agenda.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Embrace the Bittersweet With Centerbe, From Faccia Brutto
description: The Brooklyn company released another spirit made with organic herbs, botanicals and spices.
content: Faccia Brutto, the line of organic aperitivos and digestivos inspired by Italy and made in Brooklyn by Patrick Miller, a former executive chef of Rucola, has just added Centerbe. It’s made with organic herbs, other botanicals and spices. The name is that of a spirit from Abruzzo, meaning “100 herbs.” Mr. Miller stopped at 20. The pale green color suggests a comparison with Chartreuse, but it’s more bittersweet and less syrupy. It’s a pleasing digestif on its own over ice; a splash of it tones down the sweetness in a Last Word cocktail and sneaks some herbal punch into a gimlet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nagourney and Robin Pogrebin
title: After Upheaval, MOCA Bets on Johanna Burton to Bring Stability
description: She is the fifth person since 2008 to lead the Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles, an important institution that has faced a great deal of turmoil.
content: LOS ANGELES — The Museum of Contemporary Art, with its enviable collection, has long been a symbol of California’s flourishing arts scene, and it helped spur the resurgence of a once barren patch of downtown Los Angeles. But waves of management upheaval have damaged its reputation and raised questions about its prospects at a time when arts groups all over the country are struggling to regain their footing after the disruptions of the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Jacobs
title: Psilocybin Spurs Brain Activity in Patients With Depression, Small Study Shows
description: The chemical derived from psychedelic mushrooms helped alleviate symptoms of depression and generated detectable neural responses that lasted weeks.
content: Psychedelic compounds like LSD, Ecstasy and psilocybin mushrooms have shown significant promise in treating a range of mental health disorders, with participants in clinical studies often describing tremendous progress taming the demons of post-traumatic stress disorder, or finding unexpected calm and clarity as they face a terminal illness.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Healy
title: Gosar, Far-Right Incumbent, Faces G.O.P. Challengers in Arizona
description: Casting themselves as alternatives to a polarizing lawmaker, these candidates could reveal a window into the Republican electorate.
content: KINGMAN, Ariz. — Inside a flag-covered roadside pizzeria, Robert Hall slings dough with a handgun on his hip and his politics on his sleeve. He says the southern border is overrun and the 2020 election was stolen — views that would normally make a voter like him a lock to re-elect his staunchly conservative congressman, Representative Paul Gosar.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja
title: Exiled by Russian Bombs, a Ukrainian Soccer Team Embraces Its Journey
description: Shakhtar Donetsk was forced from its home city and then its country by Russian invasions. Its next stop? A series of exhibition games drawing attention to Ukraine’s plight.
content: It wasn’t the sounds of the bombs, though he did hear those, that brought back the memories for Darijo Srna. It was the air raid sirens.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear and Mujib Mashal
title: Biden Urges Modi Not to Increase India’s Reliance on Russian Oil and Gas
description: The United States hopes to convince India to come off the fence over Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, but New Delhi and Moscow have deep historic ties.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden on Monday urged Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India not to increase his country’s reliance on Russian oil and gas, officials said, part of a global effort by the United States to maintain economic pressure on Russia for its invasion of Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Salman Masood and Christina Goldbaum
title: Shehbaz Sharif Becomes Pakistan’s New Prime Minister Amid Turmoil
description: Mr. Sharif, whose family has been dogged by accusations of graft for decades, was selected by Pakistan’s Parliament at a time of deep political divisions and economic tumult.
content: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — The Pakistani Parliament selected the opposition leader Shehbaz Sharif to become the country’s prime minister on Monday, ushering in a new government after the ouster of Imran Khan and capping a week of political turmoil that pushed the fragile democracy to the brink.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles A. Kupchan
title: Putin’s War in Ukraine Is a Watershed. Time for America to Get Real.
description: How the United States should deal with Putin.
content: During his recent speech in Warsaw, President Biden said that Vladimir Putin “cannot remain in power,” only to clarify a few days later that he was merely expressing outrage, not announcing a new U.S. policy aimed at toppling Russia’s leader. The episode, interpreted by many as a dangerous gaffe, underscored the tension in U.S. foreign policy between idealism and realism.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Norimitsu Onishi and Constant Méheut
title: Macron Sets Out to Build a ‘Dam’ Against Le Pen. Can It Hold?
description: After Sunday’s vote, when nearly a third of ballots went to the extreme right, a united front of mainstream voters looked more precarious than ever.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Gulley
title: Descending Into Florida’s Underwater Caves
description: The world’s densest collection of freshwater springs is at the center of a slow-motion environmental tragedy.
content: Long before theme parks began sprouting from Orlando’s swamps, Florida’s freshwater springs were among the area’s main attractions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Goldberg
title: The Unbelievable Stupidity of Ending Global Covid Aid
description: Republican intransigence could help incubate a new variant.
content: America’s attempt to vaccinate the world against Covid is about to come to an end.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Introducing The New York Times Fellowship: A New Program
description: Seeking to cultivate journalism's next generation, The New York Times is thrilled to announce a new fellowship for recent college graduates and postgraduates.
content: Seeking to cultivate journalism's next generation, The New York Times is thrilled to announce a new fellowship for recent college graduates and postgraduates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: Compiled by John Otis
title: How Much Do You Know About Qatar?
description: Can you find Qatar on a map? What else do you know about this Middle Eastern nation with a population of almost 3 million people?
content: Can you find Qatar on a map? What else do you know about this Middle Eastern nation with a population of almost 3 million people?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Berehulak and Carlotta Gall
title: Bucha’s Month of Terror
description: We documented dozens of killings of civilians and interviewed scores of witnesses to uncover Russian atrocities in Ukraine.
content: We documented dozens of killings of civilians and interviewed scores of witnesses to uncover Russian atrocities in Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

title: What You Get for $1.9 Million in California
description: A midcentury-modern home in Rancho Mirage, a two-bedroom condominium in San Francisco and a 1954 ranch house in St. Helena.
content: A midcentury-modern home in Rancho Mirage, a two-bedroom condominium in San Francisco and a 1954 ranch house in St. Helena.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Biden Announces Gun Control Measures and A.T.F. Nominee
description: President Biden unveiled new restrictions to curb the spread of “ghost guns” during an event to announce his nomination of Steven M. Dettelbach, a former federal prosecutor, to run the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives.
content: President Biden unveiled new restrictions to curb the spread of “ghost guns” during an event to announce his nomination of Steven M. Dettelbach, a former federal prosecutor, to run the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Doctors, Attend to Your Mental Health
description: Removing the stigma from mental health care for doctors. Also: War crimes in Ukraine; the “Don’t Say Gay” law; baseball signs; Alcoholics Anonymous.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: The London Deli Salad
description: A layer of crunchy dukkah over tender beans, peas and herbs makes for quite the mezze.
content: Good morning. Yotam Ottolenghi joined The New York Times Magazine last week as an “Eat” columnist. For his first column, he wrote about the merits of hot and cold foods, and explored the concept of salad as practiced in his London delis. He gave us a recipe to go along with the prose, for a butter-bean salad with peas, herbs and pistachio dukkah (above).
source.name: The New York Times
